fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • We wrote that funding England's expanded scheme of fare concessions had left Chesterfield borough council £1.6m down and reported an official's assertion that this would equate to a 37% increase in people's council tax. In fact, it equates to an increase of about 3.6% per household. The 37% increase applies purely to the small portion of council tax that is retained by the borough council itself (after other bodies such as police, fire and county council get their share). This core portion, kept by the borough, is 9.58% of a household's council tax. The fares scheme would raise this to 13.1% of the pot (The day-tripping pensioners who are costing local councils dear, 1 August, page 9). • An obituary of the writer Frank Deasy (21 September, page 35) gave his birth year as 1960. He was born on 19 May 1959, and so was 50, rather than 49, at the time of his death. • A temporary malfunction hit the email address – published 26 September, page 8, Review – for those wanting to ask us to keep them informed of details of the 10:10 artwork auction. It is now working normally for readers wanting to get in touch (1010auction@theguardian.com). • Two items were wrong in yesterday's League One results table (page 14, Sport): Southampton should have been: draw, win, and three draws; Brighton should have been: draw, lose, win, win, draw. • Editing changes resulted in a profile of Elly Jackson of La Roux referring to the singer's "hit singles and No 1 album". The album La Roux peaked at No 2 (Where angels fear to tread, 25 September, page 3, Film & Music). It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning +44 (0)20 3353 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays. Send mail to The Readers' Editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Email: reader@theguardian.com
